content.text: Git CI/CD
What is CI/CD?
CI/CD stands for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment/Delivery .
content.html: CI/CD stands for Continuous Integration and Continuous Deployment/Delivery.

content.text: It means your code is automatically tested and deployed every time you push.
content.html: It means your code is automatically tested and deployed every time you push.

content.text: This helps you catch bugs early and deliver features faster, with less manual work.
content.html: This helps you catch bugs early and deliver features faster, with less manual work.

content.text: Why Use CI/CD?
CI/CD automates the process of testing and deploying your code. This means:
content.html: CI/CD automates the process of testing and deploying your code. This means:

content.text: How Does CI/CD Work with Git?
Every time you push code to your Git repository:
content.html: Every time you push code to your Git repository:

content.code_html: [Developer] --push--> [Git Repository] --triggers--> [CI/CD Pipeline: Test, Build, Deploy]

content.text: Popular CI/CD Services
Key CI/CD Concepts
Here are some important terms:
content.html: Here are some important terms:

content.text: Jobs
A job is a group of steps that run together. Each job runs on a runner (a server).
content.html: A job is a group of steps that run together. Each job runs on a runner (a server).

content.code:
jobs:
build:
runs-on: ubuntu-latest
steps:
# steps go here
content.code_html:
jobs:
  build:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      # steps go here

content.text: Steps
Each step is a single task, like checking out code or running tests.
content.html: Each step is a single task, like checking out code or running tests.

content.code:
steps:
- uses: actions/checkout@v3
- name: Run tests
run: npm test
content.code_html:
steps:
  - uses: actions/checkout@v3
  - name: Run tests
    run: npm test

content.text: Runners
A runner is the computer/server that runs your jobs.
content.html: A runner is the computer/server that runs your jobs.

content.text: You can use the service's runners or set up your own for more control.
content.html: You can use the service's runners or set up your own for more control.

content.text: Triggers
A trigger decides when your workflow runs.
content.html: A trigger decides when your workflow runs.

content.text: Common triggers are push (every push) and pull_request (when a pull request is opened or updated).
content.html: Common triggers are push (every push) and pull_request (when a pull request is opened or updated).

content.text: Environment Variables & Secrets
Use environment variables for settings, and secrets for passwords or API keys.
content.html: Use environment variables for settings, and secrets for passwords or API keys.

content.text: Never hardcode secrets in your code!
content.html: Never hardcode secrets in your code!

content.code_html:
env:
  NODE_ENV: production
  API_KEY: ${{ secrets.API_KEY }}

content.text: Build Logs
CI/CD tools show logs for every job and step. Check logs to see what happened or to debug failures.
content.html: CI/CD tools show logs for every job and step. Check logs to see what happened or to debug failures.

content.text: In GitHub Actions, click on a workflow run and see logs for each job/step.
content.html: In GitHub Actions, click on a workflow run and see logs for each job/step.

content.text: Skipping CI
You can skip CI/CD for a commit by adding [ skip ci ] to your commit message.
content.html: You can skip CI/CD for a commit by adding [skip ci] to your commit message.

content.text: This is useful for documentation or minor changes.
content.html: This is useful for documentation or minor changes.

content.code_html: git commit -m "Update docs [skip ci]"

content.text: Badges
Add a badge to your README to show CI/CD status.
content.html: Add a badge to your README to show CI/CD status.

content.text: This lets others see if your latest build passed.
content.html: This lets others see if your latest build passed.

content.text: Example: GitHub Actions Workflow File (Explained)

content.code:
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
# This file tells GitHub Actions how to run CI for your project

name: CI                 # The name of the workflow (shows up in GitHub)
on: [push]               # Trigger: run this workflow on every push
jobs:
build:                 # Job name (can be anything)
runs-on: ubuntu-latest   # Runner: use the latest Ubuntu server
steps:
- uses: actions/checkout@v3  # Step: check out your code from the repo
- name: Run tests            # Step: give this step a name
run: npm test              # Step: run your project's tests
content.code_html:
# .github/workflows/ci.yml
# This file tells GitHub Actions how to run CI for your project

name: CI                 # The name of the workflow (shows up in GitHub)
on: [push]               # Trigger: run this workflow on every push
jobs:
  build:                 # Job name (can be anything)
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest   # Runner: use the latest Ubuntu server
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3  # Step: check out your code from the repo
      - name: Run tests            # Step: give this step a name
        run: npm test              # Step: run your project's tests
